Diagnosis:		Metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma

Management:		Palliative chemotherapy

Histology:		Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring features

Current Situation:	Initial oncology assessment

[redacted name] is a 67-year-old gentleman recently diagnosed with metastatic colorectal cancer. He initially presented with 3-month history of increasing abdominal distension and early satiety. CT imaging demonstrated extensive peritoneal disease with omental caking and a primary sigmoid mass. Diagnostic laparoscopy on 15 March 2024 confirmed widespread peritoneal disease with a peritoneal cancer index (PCI) of 22. Biopsies confirmed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring features.

He has maintained good performance status (ECOG PS 1) despite his disease burden. His main symptoms are early satiety and mild abdominal discomfort. Weight has remained stable at 72kg. Blood results show Hb 118, normal renal and liver function, and CEA 45.

I have discussed systemic treatment options with [redacted name] and his wife. Given his good performance status, we plan to commence FOLFOX chemotherapy with careful monitoring of response. He will be reviewed after 3 cycles with CT assessment. I have arranged for PICC line insertion next week and chemotherapy teaching.
